narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Sarah Priscilla Randle  Sayd Randle
Instructor: Sarah Priscilla Randle  Sarah Randle
Instructor: Sarah Priscilla Randle  Sarah Randle
Instructor: Sarah Priscilla Randle  Sarah Randle

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Sarah Priscilla Randle  Sayd was a great teaching fellow that always provided feedback and advice on how to approach certain topics and readings we were assigned to write and discuss about. She also provided a great lecture on the research she is currently working on. She also did a great job weighing in during class discussions with interesting ideas to consider.

Instructor: Sarah Priscilla Randle  Strengths: -Able to identify student's knowledge gaps quickly during discussions -Applied theory to practical concept (final presentation) -Offered additional resources and ideas during discussions Weakness: -Does not participate much in class discussions

Instructor: Sarah Priscilla Randle  The TA was not extremely active in the discussions, however her contribution was always thoughtful and helped to bring the discussion back to the main themes. I appreciated her advice when I talked to her and thought she was very clear and concise when talking to me one-on-one. Overall an excellent TA

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: 12-13 -Professor knows material very well and is able to explain it in accessible manner -Course is well-structured, with scholars building upon one another -Drives towards one conclusion (critical towards development) although it is nuanced about why and how 14 -Course assignments are not easy but fairly rewarding.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The course provided an interesting overview of the global economy through readings from a variety of authors that focused on different geographical areas. I also enjoyed class discussions very much, allowing us to consider how the material applied to broader concepts and current events that are relevant.
Great class discussion, fascinating readings, interesting and illuminating lectures
I really liked the weekly thesis statement exercises, which helped me get a lot out of my readings and think clearly. I also enjoyed Carol's weekly lectures and the class discussions.

I like the fact that class readings covered different geographic regions. I was also happy with how the writing of the term paper was organized. for example, there was a deadline for submitting abstracts, and presenting the paper's outline. It makes you get things done on time. Compared to other term paper from other classes, this was the most organized term paper I wrote; just because it was well guided. The professor also spelled out clearly what she wanted in the paper and that helped during writing.

The reading materials and lectures fit extremely well together. Clearly a well thought-through class. Because of this the class discussions were thorough and vigorous and helped me learn the course concepts more deeply. Also the suggested reading list is excellent!

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: None!

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A
I definitely enjoyed the lectures, and think they were made more effective by the fact that we could interrupt to comment or ask questions anytime.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Highly recommend this class to everyone, no matter the subject area. Class is great for anthro students as well as business students.

For anyone studying anthropology/human geography/economics this is an excellent mid-level course on economic anthropology. Focus is on systems-theory and globalization and covers all the main theorists from Mintz to Latour.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Although I took the course initially to fulfill a course requirement, I enjoyed taking a course that applied various theoretical approaches to the understanding the of the world economy, including Marx, Foucault, Ferguson, and Latour. Overall, I really enjoyed the readings and topics in this class.
I wanted to learn to better interrogate the market economy that we are so deeply embedded in.
To get a grounding in economic anthropology theory

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Exceeded expectations
Definitely! I can't say enough of how much the class materials and discussions have inspired me. I've read and learnt a lot for this class.
-Entry into anthropological methodology -Access to various theories about development and conservation -Critical skills required for assignments Overall, class met expectations.
yes.
Yes. Superseded them

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Reflect on the broad concepts behind the readings assigned for each week and how they can be applied to your area of interest. Also, do not be intimidated by the 25 page paper! It's manageable to complete once you get into your research.
Definitely take it!
Take it! You'll learn so much. The thesis statements might take time but you'll learn to think about the readings so much better this way.

The class is amazing. The first two classes seem challenging if you have not taken a similar class in the past but you get used to doing the readings and you begin to like the class. The small class size too makes it interesting to come to class.
Do all the readings
